[code]
import java.awt.*;

public class g extends Frame{
static int z = 100;
public void paint(Graphics g){
for(int i = 0; i < 250; i++){
for(int j = 0; j < 250; j++){
if((i % 50 == 0)||(j % 50 == 0)){
double r = StrictMath.sqrt(i * i + j * j + z *z);
int x = 250 + (int)(500 * j / r);
int y = 250 + (int)(500 * i / r);
g.drawLine(x , y, x, y);
}
}
}
}
public static void main(String[] args){
g G = new g();
G.setSize(500,500);
G.show();
for(int i = 0; i < 300; i++){
z = 100 + i;
G.getGraphics().clearRect(0,0,500,500);
G.paint(G.getGraphics());
}
}
}[/code]

So here is my shitty AWT program. As you can see is flashes alot. How do I stop that flashing? I’ve heard about double - buffering, and get that it involves not trying to render the image until the image can be rendered in one shot, but don’t know how to use it. So any help?

Edit: I looked at the documentation for java/awt/Image. Basically you use Component.createImage(int width, int height).getGraphics() instead of using that components getGraphics() directly. Then you use Component.prepareImage(Image, int, int, something) to draw it.
